While Christopher Landon‚Äôs ‚ÄòDrop‚Äô is not an instant classic, it ticks all the boxes of a suspenseful thriller that, like many of Blumhouse‚Äôs projects, carries enough ingenuity and tension to justify its feature length and provide a surely entertaining ride for its audience. Some creative choices don‚Äôt always fit, and the film fails to capitalise on some of its most successful junctures. Despite this, between the pieces that fit and the ones that don‚Äôt, ‚ÄòDrop‚Äô keeps itself afloat as an effective mix of cautionary tale and whodunnit that the modern film era likely hasn‚Äôt seen the last of. It‚Äôs clear from the opening minutes that Landon recognises the necessity of realistic and relatable protagonists in order to fulfill the film's role as a warning against the petrifying realities that can unfold under the misuse of modern technology. The rising action and climax explore the increasing psychological torment of a mother facing the loss of her son while the falling action and resolution are a display of the lengths she will go to in order to save him. Meghann Fahy‚Äôs ability to balance this excursion of fear and rage with adolescent nervousness before a first date shows a talented acting range and ability to convey the magnitude of such a terrifying situation. This is matched by Brandon Skelnar‚Äôs charisma to importantly sell the impossible situation that the protagonists are sharing. The supporting characters are memorable at times, and encapsulate underlying themes presented by the writers, surrounding the struggles of online dating and chauvinism. Beyond this, these additions act merely as fuel to ravel up the mystery behind ‚ÄòLets_Play‚Äô and ultimately give ‚ÄòDrop‚Äô the legs to cross the finish line. One of the film's less successful areas is it‚Äôs stylistic choices, especially surrounding the divulgence of Violet‚Äôs torment. While the use of close ups and dolly zooms is effective in capturing isolation and fear, this idea isn‚Äôt capitalised on and is ultimately drowned out by attempts to create an unnecessary edge for an already competent concept. These misfires come in the form of large message subtitles that feel more like a parade of visual effects that were invented too many years ago to impress than a pivotal or even fitting piece in the puzzle crafted by the writers. Another unfortunate component is the falling action of the film's plot. Throughout the opening and rising action Landon expertly handles both sensitive and affable topics with care, including themes of suicide and abuse as well as the awkward yet thrilling nuances of a first date. These displays of attention and regard are tethered by the unfeasable yet predictable ending that sees two unarmed and injured women take down a trained killer with help from a child and the power of will. While this resolution is satisfying to the virtuous audience member with an understandable emotional connection to the family, who are crafted into likeable protagonists, it‚Äôs an unrealistic portrayal of a home break in that deteriorates the admirable work of the director to set up a pragmatic environment for his love interests to blossom and his leading lady to portray true trepidation. Between the experience of Fahy and Skelner, the contemporary awareness of Jillian Jacob‚Äôs writing and the brittle yet ultimately adept direction of Christopher Landon, ‚ÄòDrop‚Äô works as an effective thriller that draws suspense throughout. To audience members who look past the occasional declamatory techniques, and accept the happy ever after in turn of a conclusive cautionary tale, the film will surely entertain right up until the final Digi-Drop.

I'm not sure what surprised me the most about this film, the sheer incompetence of being able to put together a compelling and somewhat believable story, or the fact that it got better critic reviews than the new snow white film. I went to see this film as it was on my list of films to watch if nothing else is in because I have a card that lets me watch as many films as I want for a certain amount per month. And honestly I wish I hadn't seen this film or given it the time of day. Now, could this film have been good as a concept? Sure. But does it fall flat on its face for being believable and actually putting forward any sense of suspense? Yes! Honestly the only time I got any sense of suspense was during the last part of the film where I actively groaned when she's in the hospital and gets another message. Why did I groan? Because I thought they were leaving it open for a sequel and thank the lord they didn't. There were also problems regarding some of the technical aspects with this film. How many times have Mythbusters shown you don't get sucked out of a window just because there's a pressure differential? Not that there would have been a pressure differential at that altitude, not to mention there was already a hole in the window allowing for the pressure to equalise. All I can hope for is this review helps to save others from this film that if I were able to give 0 stars I would.

With remarkable performances and a tight script, Drop is a fresh return to the classic psychological and tense thrillers.

Drop (2025) is a taut, real-time thriller that blends technological paranoia with raw human emotion. During a seemingly innocent dinner date, Violet receives threatening Airdrop messages that force her into a tense game of survival to save her son and sister. The film thrives on its claustrophobic setting, sharp pacing, and natural dialogue, creating a gripping atmosphere without relying on gimmicks. Director's tight control over space and tension, complemented by polished cinematography and haunting music, keeps the audience on edge throughout. Megan Fahy delivers a compelling, layered performance, capturing both vulnerability and resilience. Despite a slightly underwhelming visual climax, Drop remains a smart, emotionally charged thriller that refreshes the genre with style and precision.

Drop, Blumhouse's second major release of 2025, is leagues better than The Woman in the Yard‚Äîbut still doesn't quite live up to the expectations set by powerhouse predecessors like The Black Phone or M3GAN (both of which, by the way, are getting sequels this year‚Äîpraise be). My opinion (that you didn‚Äôt ask for): Stream it. But before I go any further... Spoiler warning: This review contains spoilers. If you‚Äôre spoiler-averse, hit up the two-minute spoiler-free version on my TikTok (@uninvited.reviewer) or Instagram (@uninvited_reviewer). You've been warned. Emmy nominee Meghann Fahy, breakout star of The White Lotus and The Perfect Couple, plays Violet‚Äîa widowed mom venturing out on her first date in years. She arrives at a swanky restaurant and is pleasantly surprised that her date, Henry (played by It Ends with Us‚Äô Brandon Sklenar), is actually charming and handsome‚Äîtwo things dating apps rarely deliver. But the date takes a dark turn when Violet starts receiving anonymous, increasingly menacing drops to her phone. She‚Äôs told to say nothing and follow instructions‚Äîor the hooded figure on her home security camera will kill her young son and the sister babysitting him. Violet must obey every command‚Ä¶ or everyone she loves dies. The final instruction? Kill Henry. Little bit of a mood killer. Here‚Äôs the thing that bugged me most: this is a good movie. It moves fast‚Äî100 minutes, not a second wasted. The characters are relatable, charming, and appropriately evil when called for. But watching it felt oddly familiar. Then it hit me: this is basically Red Eye (2005) with a modern tech twist. When I realized it, I almost threw my arms up Charlie Brown-style and yelled, ‚ÄúARGH!‚Äù in the middle of the theater. Look, I love a sequel. But I don‚Äôt love recycling. At least not in movie plots. (Please do recycle your junk and help save the planet.) Fahy does a fantastic job as Violet, shifting convincingly between emotional vulnerability and sheer survival-mode rage as she‚Äôs forced to consider killing her date to save her family. The stakes are chilling, and the home surveillance angle is a terrifying reminder that even smart tech can‚Äôt outsmart a truly bad guy. Sklenar, as Henry, plays possibly the nicest, most patient man in cinematic history. As Violet‚Äôs behavior slides from charming to ‚ÄúShould I call a psychiatrist?‚Äù he sticks around, confused but supportive. Bless him. Honestly, Sklenar needs a hit to distract from the flaming rom-com wreckage that is It Ends With Us. (He and Jenny Slate were the only good parts of that movie, and I will die on that hill.) Unfortunately, while he gives another strong performance here, I‚Äôm not convinced this film will get the recognition he deserves. But let‚Äôs get back to the movie. The chemistry between Fahy and Sklenar carries this film far, and the casting overall is spot-on. One of the best production decisions? Setting most of the action in a restaurant 60-something floors above ground. The claustrophobic, high-stakes environment adds a ton of tension as Violet scrambles to figure out a way out of this nightmare. She‚Äôs a woman backed into a corner‚Äîand comes out swinging. Literally. She will kill to protect her family and Henry. In the third act, we finally meet the man behind the phone drops: Richard, played by Reed Diamond. It‚Äôs a refreshing twist, especially since so many thrillers opt to keep the antagonist in the shadows. Diamond‚Äôs brief but chilling performance is what ultimately bumps this movie from a ‚Äúskip it‚Äù to a ‚Äústream it.‚Äù The supporting cast is also a highlight: Gabrielle Ryan plays bartender Cara, who quickly picks up that something‚Äôs wrong and has a fabulous ‚ÄúIf your date sucks, I‚Äôll help you escape‚Äù energy. Love a woman who‚Äôs got another woman‚Äôs back. Jeffery Self plays Matt, an acrophobic waiter working in a restaurant hundreds of feet in the air. He‚Äôs awkward, oblivious, and absolutely not who you want serving your table‚Äîbut in the movie? Total scene-stealer. Final thoughts: The plot is familiar, maybe too familiar‚Äîbut the strong performances from both leads and a solid supporting cast elevate Drop enough to make it a worthwhile watch. If you‚Äôre into suspense and don‚Äôt mind a touch of d√©j√† vu, go ahead and stream it. Just maybe not on your first date. unwantedmoviereviews.com

It doesn't go overboard and is clear about its limitations, and with that in mind, its director embarks on a film that lives up to its promise quite well. A decent script that perfectly manages tension, which also takes the time to be a bit reflective about violence and abuse, but which also allows itself to find grace and humor in everyday touches that make it a film that doesn't seek to be too serious, but also not too simplistic. It's a journey that lives up to its director's promise, and with it, it delivers a pleasant pastime that is enjoyable from beginning to end, with a powerful protagonist and an atmosphere that fits perfectly to accentuate the tension. An entertaining, well-made and enjoyable film.

The Cast Is Top-Notch & The Camera-Work Works In The Storytelling. The Restaurant Setting Is Absolutely Gorgeous. The Action In The Last Act Is Solid. The Actual "Drop" Element Is A Little Sketchy As Anyone Would Likely Just Block The Sender Right Away, But That's A Very Minor Critique . The Only Other One I Had Is Thrown Out After It's Explained Why The Peros Went About Their Plan This Way Rather Than A More Straight Forward Approach, Making It More Believable. The "Who-Done-It" Angle Is Solid While Giving You Just Enough Clues But Not Too Many. There Was A Point I Figured Out Who The Peros Was, But I Don't Hold That Against The Movie, I've Just Seen Tons Of These. There Are A Couple Extra Surprise Twists In The Final Act That I Really Enjoyed. Overall, A Solid Entertaining Tense Watch That I May Even Go See Again. I'd Grade This Between An "A-" & "B+". Between 8.8/10 & A 9/10.

Well, what can I say?!!! The whole story is based on multiple, or should I say, endless ridiculous premises. For anybody who insists on watching it, stop reading here. After the typical light opening, and when it gets to the important part, any sane person would have just switched off the app, before even receiving the first really life threatening messages. But, back home, and remembering that only 18 months ago Hilda was a victim to a fake kidnapping over the phone, when she actually delivered all her jewelry to the criminals in the street, leaving her safe home at 5:30 in the morning, I realized that some folks might not be so clever to react in the correct manner from the first instant onwards. But then, when she shows the first messages to her date, a photographer for the Mayor (and later even someone way beyond this function), and he as well doesn't have the idea of blocking the app, the whole story becomes just dumb. There are soooo many things to complain about this flick, I could fill 5 pages. The worst being the window exploding as if the restaurant would be under pressure like an airplane cabin. Come on, this is beyond idiotic. +++ Not to waste more of my and your time here, it's not a complete bore, but there are surely 10.000 movies better to waste your time than with this one. 3/10!

It‚Äôs bad science fiction at best. At worst, spending your entire days watching people stare into their phones only to buy tickets to sit in a theater and watch a woman staring into her phone the entire movie is the height of dystopian irony. And it‚Äôs just plain boring. For a movie to really be effective as a thriller, the viewer has to be able to visualize a scenario where they could find themselves in that situation. And buy that it could really happen to them. Hitchcock was a master at this and why his movies are classics and precisely why nobody will even remember this movie was made in 4 years. Literally the worst and dumbest timeline to exist if you‚Äôre a fan of literature, the arts or cinema.

Drop isn‚Äôt trying to reinvent the wheel‚Äîbut it sure knows how to keep it spinning. Anchored by a tense premise and strong performances, Drop follows Violet, a widowed mother just trying to enjoy a first date at a chic restaurant. But her night quickly unravels into a high-stakes game of survival when a mysterious hooded figure begins sending threatening messages: kill your date, or your son and sister die. Most of the film takes place in one location‚Äîthe restaurant‚Äîwhich surprisingly works in its favor. The confined setting amps up the suspense and forces viewers into detective mode, scanning every background character and suspicious glance. It‚Äôs a pressure cooker of paranoia, pulsing with tech-fueled tension and tight direction. The middle of the film drags slightly, and some of the final moments lean into the unbelievable. Still, it all pays off with a conclusion that‚Äîwhile not groundbreaking‚Äîmakes sense and satisfies. The real power of Drop lies in its atmosphere and pacing. It may not be the most unpredictable thriller, but it‚Äôs certainly a gripping one. And yes, you‚Äôll want to watch it again‚Äînot because you missed the twist, but because the clues were always there, hiding in plain sight.

Tense, twisty, and totally addictive despite its flaws. Christopher Landon is back with another wild and clever thriller, and Drop might be his most intense ride yet. Known for giving us genre-benders like Happy Death Day and Freaky, Landon shifts gears a bit here, dialing up the suspense while still keeping that tight, character-driven storytelling he‚Äôs great at. The story follows Violet Gates (Meghann Fahy), a widowed mom trying to dip her toe back into dating. What starts off as a seemingly normal night out quickly spirals into a claustrophobic nightmare, she begins receiving creepy digital drops from an anonymous tormentor who‚Äôs holding her family hostage. From that point on, it‚Äôs a tense, cat-and-mouse game as Violet has to think on her feet while everyone around her becomes a potential threat. Brandon Sklenar brings a grounded charm to Henry, the date who turns out to be more tangled in the plot than expected. Violett Beane and Jeffery Self both shine in supporting roles, adding just enough personality to make the restaurant setting feel alive, and not just like a stage. What really works is how Drop balances its mystery and thriller elements with deeper emotional beats. Violet‚Äôs trauma, her guilt, her protectiveness‚Äîthose threads give the film more than just surface thrills. And the final showdown at her house is a satisfying, nail-biting conclusion to everything that‚Äôs been building. This one‚Äôs definitely worth a watch, especially if you‚Äôre into thrillers that know how to keep you guessing without overcomplicating things. Four stars from me.

In Drop, Christopher Landon delivers one of the most engaging and daring projects of his career. Using the actual functionality of airdrops - a file-sharing feature via bluetooth - as a starting point, the film throws us into a claustrophobic, distressing and surprisingly funny spiral, with a sense of urgency that holds our attention from the first few minutes to the end. The plot follows Violet, played by Meghann Fahy, during a romantic date in a restaurant that quickly turns into a nightmare. The character starts receiving spam via airdrop from an unknown sender, who appears to be physically close to her. The tension grows as she realizes that someone is watching her house in real time, and that her family is in danger if she doesn't follow threatening instructions. What was supposed to be an ordinary dinner party becomes an extreme surveillance experience, where the audience shares the same panic and paranoia as the protagonist. Landon draws from the same stylistic source as Death Congratulates You, especially in the balance between tension and comedy, but here the terror is more psychological and immediate. The restricted setting of the restaurant, a feature that could easily become tiresome, gains strength with direction that knows how to exploit every corner of the space. Every person around Violet becomes a potential threat. The presence of danger is constant, but invisible - and this makes the experience suffocating and fascinating at the same time. The script, written by Jillian Jacobs and Chris Roach, works cleverly by constructing small, seemingly banal interactions with customers and employees that later turn out to be fundamental to the unfolding of the narrative. The agile editing is a highlight. There's a dynamism that's rare in thrillers set in real time or in confined spaces, and Drop gets it right by never letting the pace drop. The tension is maintained with almost surgical efficiency, offering the viewer a journey of constant uncertainty. And even though the movie plays with the familiar ‚Äúwho's doing this to her?‚Äù formula, everything is handled with a naturalness that avoids easy shortcuts or artificial conveniences. The film also allows itself to explore denser themes, such as the trauma of abusive relationships, although this layer appears more as an emotional justification for the main character's motivations than as the center of the narrative. The idea is present, but it isn't explored in depth - which, in this case, doesn't weaken the film, since the focus is on the urgency of the present situation, and not on building a broader drama. Brandon Sklenar, as Violet's romantic partner, also holds his own well, serving both as support and as another piece in the machinery of mistrust created around the protagonist. The secondary cast fulfills their roles with functionality, and each figure introduced serves a purpose that is revealed later on, which demonstrates the script's care in putting together a puzzle where nothing is gratuitous. It's true that the third act loses some of the elegance with which the movie has been conducted. The revelation of the answers and the lead-up to the finale sound rushed and a little disjointed in pace and tone, which may annoy some viewers. Even so, it doesn't compromise the experience as a whole. The tension built up is so solid, and the identification with the protagonist so effective, that the emotional impact remains. The sense of urgency remains alive, even if the solutions presented at the end are more abrupt than ideal. Drop is a clear demonstration of Christopher Landon's ability to transform the ordinary into something extraordinary. A movie that takes a simple but thought-provoking concept and builds on it to create a suffocating, tense and engaging atmosphere. It's a work that manages to balance tension, discomfort and even hints of humor with remarkable confidence. In the end, it may not be perfect, but it's exactly the kind of movie that delivers what it promises: to keep you on the edge of your seat and make a simple cell phone notification a legitimate cause for paranoia.

This movie only works if the viewer is fully committed go getting on board AND staying on board with its premise. Although suspension of disbelief is require for all fiction stories, the strings holding the narrative of Drop are extremely thin and frail. The difficulties become even greater once the mastermind is revealed, not just who the person is but also why the person has targeted the protagonists. The mastermind must have attended the same Evil Scheme University as Lex Luthor from Batman v Superman because the mastermind's plan is absurdly complicated, could fail in over a dozen ways, and would have been easier if the villain did the job him/herself. Without offering spoilers, Drop is being compared to movies like Red Eye, Carry On, and Phone Booth because they are about masterminds coercing ordinary people into horrible situations. However, the protagonist in Drop isn't a person with special security or information access. She isn't someone that the villain targeted because of psychotic obsession. Instead, the protagonist is a woman that just happens to be on a first date with the mastermind's actual intended target. What if she had cancelled? What if her date had cancelled? What if her babysitter had cancelled? What if she dropped and damaged her phone prior to getting to the restaurant? What if she just plain turned off her phone? What if the cellphone service itself went down? (I've experience that a few times over the years.) Those are just a sample of the abundant ways the mastermind's plot would have crumbled. If the viewer can hold suspension of disbelief from start to finish, then Drop is a very entertaining, suspenseful, and surprising psychological thriller.

I really enjoyed Drop because its comedic characters take the edge off and the music helps draw us in and provides great transitions. Drop is a thriller about a young widowed mother, Violet (Meghann Fahy) who goes on her first date in years with a nice man named Henry (Brandon Sklenar). She begins to receive airdrop messages, at first assuming they are a joke, until whoever is sending her them, begins threatening her son, Toby (Jacob Robinson) and her sister, Jen (Violett Beane). She begins to wonder who this mysterious sender is and whether it might be her date? I particularly enjoyed the storyline, the acting and the background music. Noteworthy are the comedic characters, which help lighten the mood and take the edge off this thriller. For example, Violet and Henry‚Äôs waiter, Matt (Jeffery Self) plays a comedic character. His jokes and ironic statements truly lighten the mood and he steals the show; he made me look forward to his next scene. Another humorous character is Violet‚Äôs sister, Jen, who plays the part of a teasing sister. She brings humor to the scary parts of the movie and her teasing makes it seem as if she and Violet are truly family. Meghann Fahy, as Violet, is incredibly well played. During the frightening scenes her face reads of fear and I really believed she was scared during those scenes. Drop has fantastic music that provides great transitions, adding suspense and excitement ‚Äì and definitely made me hold on to my seat in anticipation. The soundtrack shifts from a scary scene to a calm scene, with smooth and unnoticeable transitions. The message of Drop is that, even when your situation is tough and it seems hopeless, never give up. Parents should be warned that there is cursing, strong violence, death, and hints of suicide. I give Drop 5 out of 5 stars and recommend it for ages 12 to 18 plus adults. It releases in theaters on April 11, 2025. By Charlotte L., KIDS FIRST!

It's definitely one of the biggest surprises of 2025 when it comes to movies. This was amazing. It was almost perfect, but it was worth checking out. Christopher Landon has outdone himself with this one. With the direction, the camera work, the premise of it. Simplistic and works well form start to finish. So as simple as the plot goes, you have Meghann Fahy going on a date with Brandon Sklenar and suddenly, Violet, Meghann's character, starts getting these drops from this unknown user demanding that she does as she is told. One screw up and both her sister, played by Violett Beane, and her son, played by Jacob Robinson, get killed. First of all, as simple as the plot is, there are times that it does get predictable, but still feel that tense moment when it comes to these messages whether it's demanding Violet to do what she's told to what has happened if she doesn't listen. I was on the edge of my seat throughout most of the movie. It's also clever that you see the messages on screen to see what the mystery person is saying while working with the camera. Again, the camera work is one of the best parts of this film. Also, I have to admit that there are times that it does get formulaic, like when Henry, Brandon's character, says to Violet that he was about to leave until she convinces him to stay. It goes the same with the messages that Violet keeps getting. You do have to keep in mind that it's an intense moment when a guy with a gun hired by the person sending the drops is in your house where your sister and son are currently in. Now, there has been more backstory for both Violet and Henry, but I don't want to spoil too much. Let's just say that it really makes you want to root for these two to get together. I do see them having great chemistry as far as their acting goes. They were great. Wanna know who is also great? Jeffery Self as Matt, their waiter. I think him and the bartender, Cara, played by Gabrielle Ryan, also carried the movie with their acting, too. I won't spoil who the person is who is sending Violet these drops. I will say that they are a great kind of mastermind as they get their comeuppance near the end of the film. One last thing to talk about is the setting alone. For a plot so simple, the location works well when it comes to being in a restaurant. Having your first date after so long is great for being original. And yes, this is certainly a date movie worth checking out with your significant other. It is still a fun watch if you're single or aromatic like myself. Certainly one of those thrillers that I recommend checking out whether in theaters or when it hits streaming services. Plus, one of Blumhouses' better movies since they are usually hit or miss, if you ask me. With that said, I'm gonna give this film nine Matt cheering Violet and Henry on their first date out of ten. 9/10.
